# Dardanian raids during the Wars of the Diadochi

The Dardanian raids during the Wars of the Diadochi (c. 284â€“281 BC) were a series of opportunistic incursions launched by the Dardani, an Illyrian people of the kingdom of Dardania, into Upper Macedonia and northern Greece during the final phase of the Wars of the Diadochi.
Background
After the death of Lysimachus at the Battle of Corupedium in 281 BC and the subsequent assassination of Ptolemy Keraunos, the Macedonian kingdom descended into a brief period of anarchy. The northern frontier garrisons were weakened or withdrawn, creating a power vacuum that the Dardani exploited.
The raids
Dardanian war bands, composed primarily of light infantry and cavalry, crossed the border and ravaged the poorly defended regions of Upper Macedonia and parts of northern Thessaly. According to ancient sources, they avoided pitched battles and focused on plunder and rapid withdrawal, a tactic typical of Illyrian frontier warfare.
The raids are mentioned only briefly in surviving sources, but modern scholarship regards them as evidence of Dardania's temporary resurgence during the collapse of centralized Macedonian authority.
Aftermath
The restoration of order under Antigonus II Gonatas after 279 BC ended the large-scale Dardanian incursions. The subsequent Gallic invasion of 279 BC shifted regional attention southward, and the Dardani themselves played a role in ambushing retreating Celtic forces later that year.
